content.raw: I'm ok with this, but @nkoenig expressed that the Noise constructor should take NoiseType as an argument, so I'll defer to him.
content.html: I'm ok with this, but @nkoenig expressed that the Noise constructor should take NoiseType as an argument, so I'll defer to him.

content.raw: It's a bit cleaner to for the Noise constructor to take a NoiseType. This will force people who sub-class Noise to specify a NoiseType.
content.html: It's a bit cleaner to for the Noise constructor to take a NoiseType. This will force people who sub-class Noise to specify a NoiseType.

content.raw: But what if the noise type is being specified in an sdf string? It seems like a hassle to have to specify it in the constructor in that case. Whoever wants to create the noise object would have to preemptively parse the sdf to identify the correct NoiseType to pass in the constructor.
content.html: But what if the noise type is being specified in an sdf string? It seems like a hassle to have to specify it in the constructor in that case. Whoever wants to create the noise object would have to preemptively parse the sdf to identify the correct NoiseType to pass in the constructor.

content.raw:
I don't believe that's an issue. The pattern here is to create a sub-class of Noise, where that sub-class has a hard-coded type.

The sdf noise string is used to indicate what sub-class to instantiate.
content.html:
I don't believe that's an issue. The pattern here is to create a sub-class of Noise, where that sub-class has a hard-coded type.

The sdf noise string is used to indicate what sub-class to instantiate.

I had the same concern as @scpeters because the following would not work:

Noise *n = new Noise(GAUSSIAN);
n->Load(...);

This means the user should always use NoiseFactory::NewNoiseModel to instantiate the noise classes?

content.raw:
You're trying to mix inheritance and composition with the factor design pattern.

`Noise` should not be used directly since it doesn't know what type of noise to generate. The factory should always be used. A subclass must be used. Therefore, you should never get into the situation of `Noise *n = new Noise(GAUSSIAN)`. This can be enforced by making some function in 'Noise` pure virtual. In fact, you probably should make ApplyImp pure virtual.
content.html:
You're trying to mix inheritance and composition with the factor design pattern.

Noise should not be used directly since it doesn't know what type of noise to generate. The factory should always be used. A subclass must be used. Therefore, you should never get into the situation of Noise *n = new Noise(GAUSSIAN). This can be enforced by making some function in 'Noise` pure virtual. In fact, you probably should make ApplyImp pure virtual.

content.raw:
I was thinking from the users' perspective when they first see the Noise API. If they don't know about the `SensorFactory` class and see that `Noise` takes a constructor, it prompts them to try out instantiating the noise class by calling its constructor with a type. 

I will update this pull request to enforce the design with virtual functions and add more doxygen comments to make it clear how the classes should be used.
content.html:
I was thinking from the users' perspective when they first see the Noise API. If they don't know about the SensorFactory class and see that Noise takes a constructor, it prompts them to try out instantiating the noise class by calling its constructor with a type.

I will update this pull request to enforce the design with virtual functions and add more doxygen comments to make it clear how the classes should be used.

content.raw:
I may be confused. In my perspective there are two different users: a user of noise and an implementor of a new type of noise.

In the first case, the user should just specify the noise type in SDF, and Gazebo handles the rest by calling the noise factory.

In the second case, the user should inherit from Noise to define their own noise. In this case we want to make sure that they specify a type, which has lead to this discussion.
content.html:
I may be confused. In my perspective there are two different users: a user of noise and an implementor of a new type of noise.

In the first case, the user should just specify the noise type in SDF, and Gazebo handles the rest by calling the noise factory.

In the second case, the user should inherit from Noise to define their own noise. In this case we want to make sure that they specify a type, which has lead to this discussion.

content.raw: ok I see. The users I was talking about are plugin developers who want to use our noise classes in their code. But it's clear now that we'll only have the factory way of creating noises so having a type argument in the constructor is ok.
content.html: ok I see. The users I was talking about are plugin developers who want to use our noise classes in their code. But it's clear now that we'll only have the factory way of creating noises so having a type argument in the constructor is ok.

content.raw:
Consider this a reply to the thread above:

I didn't understand @nkoenig 's perspective until I read this:

`Noise` should not be used directly since it doesn't know what type of noise to generate. The factory should always be used.

I was confused by that since the pull request that introduced the NoiseFactory didn't replace all instantiations of the Noise class. For example, the [GpsSensor constructor creates Noise classes directly](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/1c4756ad10093433cf103cc650f11cf026216d85/gazebo/sensors/GpsSensor.cc?at=default#cl-33):
~~~
this->horizontalPositionNoise = NoisePtr(new Noise());
~~~
The noise is then populated in [GpsSensor::Load](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/1c4756ad10093433cf103cc650f11cf026216d85/gazebo/sensors/GpsSensor.cc?at=default#cl-58):
~~~
this->horizontalPositionNoise->Load(
      posElem->GetElement("horizontal")->GetElement("noise"));
~~~

Since this wasn't changed in that pull request, I assumed that both methods were valid options. If only the factory is the right way, that's fine. I just hadn't realized that.
content.html:
Consider this a reply to the thread above:

I didn't understand @nkoenig 's perspective until I read this:

Noise should not be used directly since it doesn't know what type of noise to generate. The factory should always be used.

I was confused by that since the pull request that introduced the NoiseFactory didn't replace all instantiations of the Noise class. For example, the GpsSensor constructor creates Noise classes directly:

this->horizontalPositionNoise = NoisePtr(new Noise());

The noise is then populated in GpsSensor::Load:

this->horizontalPositionNoise->Load(
      posElem->GetElement("horizontal")->GetElement("noise"));

Since this wasn't changed in that pull request, I assumed that both methods were valid options. If only the factory is the right way, that's fine. I just hadn't realized that.

content.raw: Right, and with this pull-request no noise would ever be applied to the GpsSensor. By making ApplyImpl pure virtual, this problem will be detected at compile time.
content.html: Right, and with this pull-request no noise would ever be applied to the GpsSensor. By making ApplyImpl pure virtual, this problem will be detected at compile time.

content.raw: Just updated code to use `NoiseFactory::NewNoiseModel` for instantiating noise models. I have not made `ApplyImpl` pure virtual yet because that means we would not be able to instantiate the `Noise` class. We would then need to sublcass `Noise` with something like `EmptyNoise` and `CustomNoise` classes in order to support all noise types. So I kept the function just virtual. Let me know if that's ok or I should just make `ApplyImpl` pure virtual.
content.html: Just updated code to use NoiseFactory::NewNoiseModel for instantiating noise models. I have not made ApplyImpl pure virtual yet because that means we would not be able to instantiate the Noise class. We would then need to sublcass Noise with something like EmptyNoise and CustomNoise classes in order to support all noise types. So I kept the function just virtual. Let me know if that's ok or I should just make ApplyImpl pure virtual.

content.raw: yes when I refactored the Noise class I tried to preserve the old way of creating noises so I didn't enforce the factory design pattern.
content.html: yes when I refactored the Noise class I tried to preserve the old way of creating noises so I didn't enforce the factory design pattern.
